data.description: A comparative approach to the morphological and physiological properties of the central nervous system of animals, particularly those of veterinary importance.
data.title: VETERINARY NEUROANATOMY AND NEUROPHYSIOLOGY

data.description: A detailed consideration of gross anatomical structure with emphasis on major anatomical patterns present in species important to veterinary medicine. The dog is used as a model domestic mammal and comparisons with other species are considered. All body systems are dissected. Clinical implications of these dissections are emphasized.
data.title: FUNDAMENTAL PRINCIPLES OF VETERINARY ANATOMY

data.description: A study of the horse and the ox with special emphasis on the anatomical specializations of these species with extensive comparisons to the anatomy of the small domestic animals. Other large domestic animals, including swine, will be considered as appropriate to demonstrate anatomical variation.
data.title: ANATOMY OF THE LARGE DOMESTIC ANIMALS

data.description: Basic pharmacology of various drug classes used in veterinary medicine together with examples of clinical drug use. Important species variations in drug use and drug response will be stressed.
data.title: VETERINARY PHARMACOLOGY

data.description: Covers comparative veterinary physiology covering digestive, endocrine, and reproductive systems.
data.title: VETERINARY PHYSIOLOGY B

data.description: Covers comparative veterinary physiology covering electrophysiology, and muscle, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal and acid-base physiology.
data.title: VETERINARY PHYSIOLOGY A

data.description: Covers metabolism with a more advanced incorporation of concepts of chemistry, cell biology and physiology. Clinical correlations in veterinary medicine are also covered.
data.title: MOLECULAR AND METABOLIC BASIS OF MEDICINE

data.description: Light and digital microscopy are used to study the anatomy of organs and tissues at the cellular level. Microanatomic features of all major organ systems are identified, and pertinent physiologic concepts are discussed to correlate structure with function. Mammalian systems are emphasized, and comparisons to non-mammalian species are considered. Direct applications to clinical medicine are included.
data.title: VETERINARY HISTOLOGY

data.description: Offers opportunities for faculty coordinated experience in the veterinary medical profession outside School of Veterinary Medicine.
data.title: EXTERNSHIP

data.description: Principles of development and organogeneses in domestic animals. Normal developmental patterns are related to adult anatomy. Clinical implications of common congenital defects are discussed.
data.title: VETERINARY DEVELOPMENTAL ANATOMY

data.description: Projects in the laboratory and/or through library work in specific subject area under the direct guidance of faculty member.
data.title: DIRECTED STUDY

data.description: Provides instruction in principles and concepts of research ethics through presentations and discussion of case studies. Topics pertinent to development of a successful career in research are also included.
data.title: RESEARCH ETHICS AND CAREER DEVELOPMENT

data.description: Science of toxicology as it relates to veterinary practice. The principles of toxicology and the mechanism and treatment of toxicants commonly encountered in small and large animals will be presented.
data.title: VETERINARY TOXICOLOGY
